Thoughts on a theory of adaptation

May 8, 2019 • arzwa

After reading (or trying to read) this new PCI Evol. Biol. paper, I read Orr (2005)1 today, and what struck me is the complete absence of an account of the more ‘genome evolution’ related processes and how they contribute to adaptation in theoretically inclined work. Fisher’s geometric model, the NK models, the mutational landscape model, none of these accounts for evolutionary facts like duplication loss and genome rearrangements.

Fisher’s Geometrc model (FGM) is cool because of it’s quantitative genetics elegance, ‘statistical mechanics’-style (as Orr also explicitly notes). That is of course one of its problems, since nowadays we’d like to model evolution in terms of what happens at the genetic level more explicitly. The other models address this, since they consider ‘sequence space’. However they are confined to single genes, and are typically envisaged (I guess?) in rather concrete adaptational challenges, like those encountered in microbial evolution (and evolutionary experiments). For ‘complex’ organisms and more ‘general’ adaptive challenges (an organism moving to a different and unsuitable climate) the FGM is more appealing with it’s account of pleiotropy and it’s applicability to complex quantitative traits.

But then I start thinking about what these genomes actually look like, and there is obviously a lot more going on than the kind of popgen models of Gillespie and others. In plants at least, genomes seem very ‘dynamic’, and from the looks of it, these genomes are dominated by TE activity, duplication, loss, rearrangement and WGD. To me, and probably many other evolutionary biologists not entirely focusing on popgen, it would seem (perhaps naively) that stuff like duplication and loss are major sources of adaptation (and speciation, divergence etc). These kinds of processes of course do fit in to some degree in the FGM, since this is only defined at a phenotypic level (with strong assumptions on the quantitative genetics of course).
